Article.ArticleTitle: Ambient ozone over mid-Brahmaputra Valley, India: effects of local emissions and atmospheric transport on the photostationary state.

AbstractText: This study presents the characteristics of ground level atmospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) over the rural mid-Brahmaputra Valley region of the northeastern India. Ozone and oxides of nitrogen (NO<sub>x</sub> = NO + NO<sub>2</sub>) concentration data were obtained from continuous measurement of O<sub>3</sub> and NO<sub>x</sub> housed at the MAPAN-AQM station at Tezpur University. The meteorological parameters were obtained from the same station. The diel, monthly, and seasonal variations of O<sub>3</sub> were studied. The O<sub>3</sub>-NO<sub>x</sub> photostationary state (PS) was carefully examined and it was found that the net O<sub>3</sub> concertation deviated substantially from the PS during the winter season. The deviation could be attributed to local biomass burning, biogenic VOC emission from forest and agriculture, and long-range transport of peroxyacyl nitrate (PAN). The long-range transport has been ascertained by examining the ventilation coefficients (VC), which correlated with the steep growth of net O<sub>3</sub> concentrations in the morning hours. The HYSPLIT air mass back trajectories were used in concentration-weighted trajectory (CWT) analyses of O<sub>3</sub> to assess the long-range regional transport of O<sub>3</sub> precursors, which positively influenced local O<sub>3</sub> concentrations.
